The symmetric group, denoted as $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, is the group of all bijective self-maps of the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$.
Sign or Signature of a Permutation

The sign or signature of a permutation $\pi \in \mathfrak{S}_{n}$, denoted as $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$, is defined by the product $\prod_{i<j} \frac{\pi(i)-\pi(j)}{i-j}$. The sign can only assume the values 1 and -1. If $\operatorname{sgn} \pi$ is positive, $\pi$ is called an even permutation, and an odd permutation otherwise.
Does the concept of a/an Symmetric Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Sign or Signature of a Permutation to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the sign or signature of a permutation explicitly references the symmetric group, denoted as \(\mathfrak{S}_{n}\). The sign of a permutation \(\pi\) is defined for permutations that are elements of the symmetric group \(\mathfrak{S}_{n}\). Therefore, the concept of the symmetric group is essential for defining the domain of the function that assigns a sign to a permutation. Without the concept of the symmetric group, the definition of the sign of a permutation would lack a clear and necessary context, as it would be unclear what set of permutations the sign function applies to. Thus, the concept of a symmetric group is needed for the definition of the sign or signature of a permutation to make sense.
